title: National Portable Video Camera WV-3085
brief_description: The Portapak system is a handheld video camera with separate reel-to-reel video recorder. It enabled videos to be captured and played back more quickly while also cutting down on the cost, which led to the birth of video art, guerrilla television and activism.

constellations_primary.name: Access to resistance
constellations_primary.description: This Constellation explores how access to new recording devices has inspired guerilla filmmaking and protest, helping challenge cultural, societal and political norms.

description: The Portapak system consists of a handheld video camera with a separate reel-to-reel video recorder in a portable pack that could be carried over the shoulder. The style was first released by Sony in 1967 and was an important development in camera technology, enabling a new level of portability with both the camera and recorder battery-powered and self-contained. It enabled videos to be captured and played back more quickly while also cutting down on the cost, which led to the birth of video art, guerrilla television and activism. In the 1970s, the Portapak was popular with video artists and alternative media collectives. In Australia, Open Channel and the Paddington Video Access Centre used Portapaks to create alternative broadcast channels, paving the way for community television.
